description: Inherited from Middle English squelen, probably from Old Norse skvala (“to squeal, bawl”), from Proto-Germanic *skwel- (“to chatter, babble, scream”), perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *skel-, from *kelh₁- (“to ring, resound, cry”). Compare Old Norse skval (“a squeal”, noun), Swedish skvallra (“to babble, chatter, tell on”).

entries.meaning: A high-pitched sound, such as the scream of a child or a female person, or noisy worn-down brake pads.

verbs.description: squeal (third-person singular simple present squeals, present participle squealing, simple past and past participle squealed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To scream with a shrill, prolonged sound.
examples: I made my girlfriend squeal with delight last night.

entries.meaning: (of an object) To make a squealing noise.
(intransitive, slang) To give sensitive information about someone to a third party; to rat on someone.
